title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with evidence showing disparities in legal representation and execution rates. The House Judiciary Subcommittee found that 89 percent of defendants selected for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. Additionally, a 1990 report by the General Accounting Office highlighted racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty. Prisoner appeals have also been significantly limited. Prisoner appeals have been severely curtailed, increasing the risk of imprisonment and execution of innocent people. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and sentences in Federal courts, even when presenting compelling evidence of innocence. Legislation in 1996 limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal and State death penalty is on hold until Congress reviews the final findings of the National Commission on the Death Penalty and enacts legislation based on their recommendations. The National Commission on the Death Penalty has been established. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, and judges. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters from the public or private sector. The Commission aims to have a balanced viewpoint in its membership composition. The National Commission on the Death Penalty aims for balanced membership regarding opinions on the death penalty. Initial members must be appointed within 30 days of enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies filled in the same manner. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed and will meet at the Chairperson's call. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The President designates a member to serve as Chair of the Commission, which must adopt rules and procedures for its proceedings. SEC. 202. Duties of the Commission. The Commission is required to conduct a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles of fairness, justice, equality, and due process. This study will include examining racial disparities, disproportionality based on geographic location and income status, and the adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The Commission is tasked with conducting a thorough study on the administration of the death penalty, including considerations of legal guidelines and policies for counsel in capital cases, wrongful convictions, federal involvement in states without the death penalty, and the adequacy of judicial review in post-conviction proceedings. The Commission is studying the administration of the death penalty, including sentencing mentally retarded and juvenile offenders, access to forensic evidence, and ensuring fair and impartial administration of death penalty cases. Guidelines and procedures will be established based on the study. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for the fair and impartial administration of the death penalty, aiming to minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals and prevent racial discrimination. A preliminary report will be submitted to the President, Attorney General, and Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commission will submit a preliminary report with initial findings and conclusions. A final report, due within 2 years of the Act's enactment, will include detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary to carry out its duties under this title. The Commission has the authority to gather information, including taking testimony and receiving evidence through subpoenas issued by the Chairperson for enforcement in case of non-compliance. The Commission can issue subpoenas for testimony or evidence, and failure to comply may result in contempt charges. A court can also issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission. Witnesses requested or subpoenaed to appear at Commission hearings will receive allowances and fees as per section 1821 of title 28, United States Code, paid from Commission funds. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws, subject to confirmation by the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff members without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and the Chairperson can also procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. The Commission may spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
